sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving solutions
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change (in kJ/mol) for the following reaction involving solutions:
 
NaOH(aq) + HCl(aq) → NaCl(aq) + H2O(l)

Given the following enthalpy values:

NaOH(aq): -469.2 kJ/mol  
HCl(aq): -167.2 kJ/mol  
NaCl(aq): -411.2 kJ/mol  
H2O(l): -285.8 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the formula:

ΔH_reaction = Σ ΔH_products - Σ ΔH_reactants

where ΔH_reaction is the standard enthalpy change of the reaction, ΔH_products are the enthalpy values of the products, and ΔH_reactants are the enthalpy values of the reactants.

For this reaction, the reactants are NaOH(aq) and HCl(aq), and the products are NaCl(aq) and H2O(l). Using the given enthalpy values, we can calculate the standard enthalpy change as follows:

ΔH_reaction = [(-411.2 kJ/mol) + (-285.8 kJ/mol)] - [(-469.2 kJ/mol) + (-167.2 kJ/mol)]

ΔH_reaction = (-696.0 kJ/mol) - (-636.4 kJ/mol)

ΔH_reaction = -59.6 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction is -59.6 kJ/mol.
